title: Day 1 - Predict the Future
mainPromise: You will define what success in 27 days means for you, with clear constraints that keep your idea search realistic.

teachings.title: Define the change you want
teachings.content:
A side hustle is not only an activity. It is a change in your life. If you do not name the change, you will chase random ideas and waste time.

Think in outcomes, not tasks. Start a small online service is a task. Reduce my monthly money stress by earning $200 is an outcome. Outcomes help you choose ideas that fit.

Keep the timeframe honest. You are building something alongside a normal life. Your target should be specific and reachable within 27 days, even if it is small.
teachings.soWhat: If you cannot state your 27-day outcome clearly, you cannot evaluate ideas or make tradeoffs.

teachings.title: Choose a focus lens
teachings.content:
Ideas multiply when you look through a lens. The simplest lens is: who is the customer, what result do they want, and what is the smallest promise you can deliver digitally.

Busy people who want a clear result is a fine starting customer. It is broad, but it points you toward problems that feel urgent: time, confusion, missed deadlines, repeated frustration.

A good promise has a before and after that someone can recognize. Save time and reduce frustration becomes stronger when you tie it to a concrete situation like inbox overload, messy scheduling, or unclear study plans.
teachings.soWhat: If you define the customer and promise today, your idea list tomorrow will be specific instead of random.

teachings.title: Set your decision rules
teachings.content:
You will have more ideas than time. Decision rules protect your time. They also reduce regret because you can explain why you chose something.

A decision rule is not a motivational quote. It is a boundary like: I only pursue ideas I can deliver digitally within 7 days, or I only pursue ideas where I can explain the value in one sentence.

Also create a place to store assumptions. Assumptions are not bad. Unwritten assumptions are bad. When you write them down, you can test them later.
teachings.soWhat: If you do not set decision rules, you will keep changing direction and calling it research.

title: Day 2 - Learn How Money Grows on Trees
mainPromise: You will build a practical idea-quality filter and use it to shape idea seeds that can realistically earn money soon.

teachings.title: Feasibility is about shipping
teachings.content:
A feasible idea is not the easiest idea. It is the idea you can actually deliver without breaking your constraints from Day 1.

Feasibility is mostly logistics: time, skills, tools, and steps. If you cannot outline the first week of delivery, the idea is not ready for this 27-day sprint.

Think like a small online service operator. The service should be deliverable digitally, repeatable, and simple enough to start while you are still learning. Complexity can come later if it earns the right to exist.
teachings.soWhat: If you do not define feasibility in concrete terms, you will pick ideas that sound good but cannot launch.

teachings.title: Profit needs a clear path
teachings.content:
Profit is not only revenue. It is revenue minus the real costs of delivery, including your time. Early on, your best path is usually a simple first transaction, not a long-term grand plan.

A profitable idea has a buyer, a reason they pay, and a price that makes sense against effort. If you cannot see how money changes hands, you do not have an idea yet. You have a wish.

Keep it grounded. In the first month, aim for small but real income, like $100 to $300. That forces clarity: how many customers, at what price, through what channel.
teachings.soWhat: If you do not map the first transaction, you will build a service that cannot sell.

teachings.title: Persuasion is about timing
teachings.content:
People buy when the pain is present, the result is clear, and the risk feels low. Persuasion is not hype. It is fit between a moment and an offer.

A persuasive idea can be explained quickly. It has a why now that makes sense. It reduces uncertainty by making the next step obvious: what happens after payment, what they receive, and when.

For a small online service, persuasion often comes from specificity: a clear deliverable, a tight timeframe, and a narrow problem that is common among busy people.
teachings.soWhat: If your offer does not feel timely and low-risk, people delay, and delayed buyers do not become buyers.

title: Day 3 - Brainstorm, Borrow, or Steal Ideas
mainPromise: You will generate a set of qualified ideas and capture the best ones in consistent idea snapshots.

teachings.title: Generate ideas in batches
teachings.content:
Waiting for inspiration is unreliable. Instead, you will generate ideas in batches using repeatable prompts. Batches reduce pressure and increase variety.

Use three sources: your own recurring frustrations, other people's visible problems, and existing offers you can adapt. This keeps your ideas grounded in reality and payment behavior.

Do not judge too early. The goal in the first pass is volume with basic fit to your filter: can it be delivered digitally, can it be sold soon, and is the benefit clear.
teachings.soWhat: If you do not create volume, you will over-commit to your first idea and miss better options.

teachings.title: Turn seeds into snapshots
teachings.content:
A seed is a headline. A snapshot is an idea you can compare. Snapshots force you to define customer, promise, delivery, and payment path without writing a business plan.

Keep snapshots short. You are not trying to be clever. You are trying to be clear. A snapshot should fit on one screen and be easy to score later.

Use your default learner context if you have nothing else: a small online service for busy people, promising time savings and less frustration, delivered digitally.
teachings.soWhat: If you do not standardize your idea descriptions, you cannot compare them fairly.

teachings.title: Select candidates worth deeper work
teachings.content:
Selection is not commitment. It is prioritization. You are choosing which ideas deserve more thinking tomorrow.

A good candidate usually has one of these advantages: easy delivery, clear buyer pain, repeatable demand, or an obvious reason to choose you (speed, clarity, niche focus).

Use simple scoring. Avoid long debates with yourself. Write down why an idea wins. That written reason becomes a useful constraint later.
teachings.soWhat: If you do not narrow down today, Day 4 becomes messy and slow.

title: Day 4 - Weigh the Obstacles and Opportunities of Each Idea
mainPromise: You will identify what could block each top idea, what could make it easier, and what you will do about it.

teachings.title: Obstacles are not excuses
teachings.content:
An obstacle is any factor that increases time, cost, or uncertainty. Naming obstacles is not negativity. It is planning.

Most obstacles fall into a few buckets: unclear customer, hard delivery, hard to get attention, high competition, or too much custom work. When you label the bucket, you can choose a response.

The goal today is not to solve everything. The goal is to see the real shape of the work so you can avoid ideas that become heavy too fast.
teachings.soWhat: If you do not list obstacles now, you will discover them later when they are expensive.

teachings.title: Opportunities are leverage
teachings.content:
Opportunities are not vague upsides. They are specific advantages that reduce effort or increase willingness to pay.

Common opportunities for a small online service include: repeatable demand, clear urgency windows, easy referrals, a niche where people already pay, and assets you already have (templates, skills, experience, audience).

If you can name opportunities clearly, you can design the offer to use them. For example, if urgency peaks weekly, you can sell a weekly reset service. If referrals are natural, you can build a referral ask into delivery.
teachings.soWhat: If you do not name opportunities, you will build a generic offer that competes on price.

teachings.title: Reduce the work to experiments
teachings.content:
You do not have to solve every risk. You need a small experiment that reduces the biggest uncertainty.

Experiments should be cheap and fast. Examples: write a one-paragraph offer and see if someone replies, post a simple form and see if anyone fills it, or run a 10-minute call with a friend to test clarity (only if calls fit your constraints).

Today you will decide what you can test next week, and what you should avoid entirely.
teachings.soWhat: If you do not convert risks into experiments, you will keep thinking instead of moving.

title: Day 5 - Forecast Your Profit on the Back of a Napkin
mainPromise: You will estimate profit potential for your leading ideas using simple math, written assumptions, and realistic capacity.

teachings.title: Profit is a few simple numbers
teachings.content:
You do not need advanced finance to forecast profit. You need a small set of inputs and honest assumptions.

Start with units: price per sale, time per delivery, and variable costs. Then add capacity: how many sales you can deliver per week within your time budget.

When you write these numbers down, you can compare ideas that feel similar. One idea may look exciting but collapses when you realize it needs 6 hours per customer. Another may look boring but pays well because it is repeatable and fast.
teachings.soWhat: If you do not quantify effort and price, you cannot choose ideas that actually improve your life.

teachings.title: Capacity makes forecasts real
teachings.content:
Your calendar is the real limit. A side hustle that requires high touch time has a hard ceiling.

Capacity is: weekly time budget divided by time per delivery. If you have 3 hours per week and each delivery takes 90 minutes, your weekly capacity is 2 customers. That is not a judgment. It is a fact you can work with.

Also consider support time. Digital services still create questions, revisions, and follow-up. Add a small buffer so you do not lie to yourself.
teachings.soWhat: If you do not calculate capacity, you will set goals that create stress instead of freedom.

teachings.title: Choose based on payback and simplicity
teachings.content:
Your best idea for this sprint is usually the one that pays back your time quickly and stays simple enough to deliver repeatedly.

Use two final checks. First, payback: profit per hour should beat what you could earn from an extra shift or basic freelancing. Second, simplicity: the idea should not require heavy customization to be valuable.

You are not picking a forever business. You are picking the best next step. A good week-one choice is an idea you can sell, deliver, and learn from without burning out.
teachings.soWhat: If you do not choose decisively now, you will drift into Week 2 without a strong candidate.

title: Use the Side Hustle Selector to Compare Ideas
goal: Pick one primary idea and one backup using a five-factor scoring system
hook: Debate ends today. You will score, rank, and commit to one idea for the next phase.

lesson.title: Why Today Matters
lesson.content:
You have been exploring. Now it is time to decide. Indecision is expensive. Every day you spend debating is a day you are not building, testing, or earning. Today you stop the loop.

The goal is not to find a perfect idea. Perfect ideas do not exist. The goal is to find a good enough idea that matches your situation and commit to testing it properly. Commitment unlocks energy. Hesitation drains it.

You will use a five-factor system to rank your ideas:

Feasibility. Can you actually do this with your current skills, time, and resources? An idea you cannot execute is not an idea. It is a fantasy.

Profitability. Does the math work? Can you sell this at a price that leaves meaningful profit after costs and your time?

Persuasion. Is there a clear reason to buy now? Does this solve a problem that feels urgent or painful? Can you explain it in one sentence?

Efficiency. How fast can you launch and test? Ideas that require months of prep before you can get feedback are dangerous for part-time hustlers.

Motivation. How excited are you? You will need to push through hard moments. If you feel nothing, that matters.

Score each idea on these five factors. Add the scores. Rank them. Then pick your primary and backup.

Your primary idea is the one you commit to for the next seven days. Your backup is the fallback if something fundamental breaks. Everything else gets shelved. You can return to those ideas later if needed.

Do not overthink the scoring. Use your gut combined with what you learned on Days 1 through 5. The point is to end debate, not to find mathematical certainty.

practice.title: The Decision Reset (3-5 minutes)
practice.content:
Before you score, reset your mental state.

Close your eyes. Take three slow breaths. Notice any tightness in your body. That tension often comes from wanting to make the right choice. Acknowledge it.

Now remind yourself: there is no perfect choice. There is only a choice you make and then work to validate. The goal today is forward motion, not perfection.

Set a timer for 2 minutes. On paper or in your head, answer these questions without filtering:

1. Which idea excites me most right now?
2. Which idea feels most doable this week?
3. Which idea do I keep coming back to?

Write down your answers. These are signals. Now open your eyes and begin the scoring process.

mission.task: Complete the Decision Reset practice
List your top 4 ideas from Days 3 through 5
Score each idea on Feasibility (1 to 5)
Score each idea on Profitability (1 to 5)
Score each idea on Persuasion (1 to 5)
Score each idea on Efficiency (1 to 5)
Score each idea on Motivation (1 to 5)
Total scores and rank ideas from highest to lowest
Choose your primary idea and backup idea
Write your commitment: For the next 7 days, I will focus on _____

commonMistakes:
Scoring all ideas the same to avoid deciding. The point of scoring is to create separation. Be honest about differences.

Ignoring motivation because it seems soft. Low motivation kills execution. If you dread the work, factor that in.

Picking the hardest idea because it feels more impressive. Harder is not better. Faster feedback is better.

Not committing to one primary idea. Keeping two ideas equally active splits your energy and guarantees slower progress.

Overthinking the scoring. This is not a math test. Use your judgment and move on.

Forgetting to pick a backup. If your primary idea fails fast, you want a clear fallback so you do not stall.
doneMeans: You have scored and ranked your ideas, chosen one primary and one backup, and written a commitment sentence.
reviewCTA: Want feedback on your scoring logic? Submit your Day 6 workbook for review and get suggestions on your idea selection.

title: Become a Detective
goal: Research your market and find a clear angle to differentiate
hook: Competition is proof of demand. Today you study it, find the gaps, and claim your angle.

lesson.title: Why Today Matters
lesson.content:
You picked an idea. Now you need to know what you are walking into. The worst mistake is to build in a vacuum. If you do not know what exists, you cannot position yourself differently.

Today you become a detective. You will research competitors, study their offers, read their reviews, and look for patterns. This is not about copying. It is about understanding.

Here is the good news: competition means demand. If people are already paying for something similar, there is a market. The absence of competition usually means the absence of buyers, not untapped opportunity.

Here is what you are looking for:

What do competitors offer? Study the specifics. What is included, what is not, how is it priced, how is it delivered?

What do customers complain about? Read reviews, comments, and forum threads. Complaints are opportunities. Each frustration is a chance to do something better or different.

What is missing? Sometimes no one offers exactly what a segment wants. That gap is your angle.

Your goal is not to be the best in the world. That is unrealistic and unnecessary. Your goal is to be different enough that you have a reason to exist. You need a clear answer to: why would someone choose you instead of the others?

The answer might be: you are faster, cheaper, more personal, more specialized, local, or more trustworthy. Any angle works if it is true and you can deliver on it.

By the end of today, you will have a short statement: I am different because _____. That statement guides everything you build.

practice.title: The Detective Scan (5-7 minutes)
practice.content:
Set a timer for 6 minutes. You are going to do a quick reconnaissance sweep.

Open Google, YouTube, and one marketplace (Etsy, Fiverr, Upwork, or similar depending on your idea).

Search for your offer or problem in simple terms. Example: resume help, meal planning service, logo design.

For the first 3 minutes, skim results. Do not click. Just notice: how many results? What prices do you see? What promises?

For the next 3 minutes, click into 2 or 3 competitors. Skim their offer page and read 2 reviews or comments.

When the timer ends, write down three things:

1. One thing competitors do well.
2. One thing customers complain about.
3. One gap no one seems to fill.

These notes are your starting point for deeper research.

mission.task: Complete the Detective Scan practice
Search 3 to 5 platforms for competitors (Google, YouTube, Etsy, Fiverr, Reddit, etc.)
Document details for 5 competitors: name, link, offer, price, main promise
For each competitor, note what seems weak or missing
Collect 5 phrases customers use in reviews or comments
Write 3 gap hypotheses: things you could do differently
Choose your differentiation angle
Write your statement: I am different because _____

commonMistakes:
Panicking at competition. Competition confirms demand. It is a good sign.

Only looking at the first page of Google. Check marketplaces, social media, and forums too.

Stopping after 2 competitors. Look at 5. Patterns appear after you see more examples.

Ignoring negative reviews. Complaints are signals. They tell you what to fix.

Copying competitors instead of differentiating. The goal is to find your unique angle, not to clone someone else.

Choosing an angle you cannot deliver. Your differentiation must be true. Do not claim premium if you cannot deliver premium.
doneMeans: You have documented 5 competitors, found 3 gaps, and written a differentiation statement.
reviewCTA: Want feedback on your differentiation angle? Submit your Day 7 workbook for review.

title: Have Imaginary Coffee with Your Ideal Customer
goal: Create a vivid avatar and understand what drives them to pay
hook: Stop selling to everyone. Today you meet the one person your offer is built for.

lesson.title: Why Today Matters
lesson.content:
Everyone is not your customer. If you try to serve everyone, you will resonate with no one. The most effective side hustles are built for a specific person with a specific problem.

Today you create your avatar. Not a demographic profile. A real human you can picture.

Think about someone who would genuinely benefit from your offer. Maybe it is someone you know. Maybe it is a version of yourself from a few years ago. Maybe it is someone you have observed online or in real life.

Give them a name. Picture their day. Understand their frustration.

Go beyond surface details. Yes, know their age and job. But more importantly, know what keeps them up at night. Know what they have tried and why it failed. Know what they secretly want and what they fear will happen if nothing changes.

Know their objections. What makes them hesitate to spend money? What would make them trust you? What outcome would make them feel like they got their money's worth?

When you understand this person deeply, your marketing becomes easier. You stop guessing what to say. You just say what they need to hear.

By the end of today, you will have a one-page avatar summary. You will also write a short letter to this person. The letter is not something you send. It is an exercise to prove you understand them. If you can write it without sounding fake, you are ready to sell.

practice.title: The Coffee Chat Visualization (5-7 minutes)
practice.content:
Close your eyes. Imagine you are sitting across from your ideal customer at a quiet coffee shop.

They look tired. They have a problem they want to solve. They are skeptical but open.

For 2 minutes, imagine them talking. What do they say? What words do they use? What frustration shows in their voice?

Now imagine yourself responding. You are not pitching. You are just listening and occasionally asking questions. What do you ask?

Open your eyes. Set a timer for 3 minutes. Write down:

1. Their biggest complaint in their own words.
2. What they tried before and why it disappointed them.
3. What they secretly want but feel embarrassed to admit.

These notes become the foundation of your avatar.

mission.task: Complete the Coffee Chat Visualization practice
Give your avatar a name and a one-line identity
Fill in basic profile: age range, role, location type
Describe their biggest frustration related to your offer
Describe what they fear will happen if nothing changes
Describe what they secretly want
List what they have tried before and why it failed
Describe what would make them trust you
Write 8 quick Q and A notes from your imaginary conversation
Write a short letter to your avatar (150 to 250 words)

commonMistakes:
Making the avatar too broad. Everyone aged 25 to 45 is not specific enough.

Focusing only on demographics. Age and income matter less than problems and motivations.

Inventing a fictional person with no grounding in reality. Base your avatar on real observations.

Skipping the letter exercise. Writing to them forces you to prove you understand them.

Using marketing language in the letter. Write like a human, not a brochure.

Ignoring objections and distrust. Knowing what makes them hesitate is as important as knowing what they want.
doneMeans: You have a one-page avatar summary with profile, frustrations, desires, and a short letter written to them.
reviewCTA: Want feedback on your avatar? Submit your Day 8 workbook for review and get suggestions on deepening your understanding.

title: Transform Your Idea into an Offer
goal: Package your idea into a clear, sellable offer with promise, pitch, and price
hook: An idea is a thought. An offer is something someone can buy. Today you build the package.

lesson.title: Why Today Matters
lesson.content:
You have an idea and an avatar. But ideas do not sell. Offers do. An offer is specific, bounded, and priced. It answers the question: what exactly do I get if I pay you?

Vague offers create confusion. Confusion kills sales. If a potential customer cannot understand your offer in 30 seconds, they will not buy.

Today you define your offer with precision:

What do they receive? List the deliverables. A course? A call? A template? A product? Be concrete.

What problem does it solve? State the problem in their words, not industry jargon. If your avatar would not use a word, do not use it.

What outcome can they expect? Outcomes are what people pay for. Not the thing itself, but what the thing does for them.

How is it delivered? In person, online, via email, on a call? Be clear.

How long does it take? Same day, a week, a month?

What is not included? Boundaries prevent scope creep and set expectations.

What does it cost? Price it simply. One-time, hourly, package, or subscription.

You will also write two pitches. The first is one sentence. This is your cocktail party answer to what do you do. The second is five sentences. This is for a landing page or longer conversation.

Finally, you will consider a basic version and a premium version. Not because you need both, but because thinking in tiers helps clarify value.

By the end of today, you have a sellable offer. Not perfect. Not final. But clear enough that you could describe it to a stranger and they would understand.

practice.title: The Promise and Boundaries Exercise (4-6 minutes)
practice.content:
Set a timer for 5 minutes.

Answer these questions without stopping to edit:

1. After someone pays me, what do they walk away with? (The deliverable)
2. What changes for them? (The outcome)
3. What am I definitely not doing for them? (The boundary)

Now reread your answers. Circle any vague words. Replace them with specifics.

Example: Help them with their resume becomes Rewrite their resume and record a 10-minute video explaining the changes.

Example: Support during the process becomes Two 30-minute calls plus unlimited email for 14 days.

Specificity is your friend. Vague promises sound weak.

mission.task: Complete the Promise and Boundaries exercise
Write your offer name
Write who it is for (from your Day 8 avatar)
Write the promise in plain language
List the deliverables: what exactly do they receive
Choose delivery format and time to deliver
Write what is not included
Write your one-sentence pitch
Write your five-sentence pitch
Set your price model and price point
Describe basic version and premium version differences

commonMistakes:
Being vague about deliverables. They get a course is not enough. How many modules? How long? What format?

Using jargon the avatar would not understand. Write in their language.

Skipping boundaries. Without clear limits, you risk scope creep and resentment.

Pricing before understanding value. Think about what outcome is worth to them, not just what it costs you.

Writing the pitch in marketing speak. Write like you talk. Authenticity beats polish.

Trying to be everything to everyone. A focused offer beats a broad one.

Forgetting risk reversal. What happens if they are not happy? Have an answer.

Not thinking about where to find the first 3 customers. Your offer is useless if no one sees it.
doneMeans: You have a clear offer with name, promise, deliverables, boundaries, pitches, and price.
reviewCTA: Want feedback on your offer? Submit your Day 9 workbook for review and get suggestions on clarity and pricing.

title: Create Your Origins Story
goal: Craft a true, simple story that builds trust and connection
hook: People buy from people they trust. Your story is how they decide to trust you.

lesson.title: Why Today Matters
lesson.content:
You have an offer. Now you need a reason for people to listen. That reason is your story.

People do not buy from faceless businesses. They buy from humans with motives, experiences, and credibility. Your origin story answers the questions: Why are you doing this? Why should I believe you can help me?

This is not about bragging. It is not about inventing drama. It is about honest connection.

A good origin story follows a simple arc:

You noticed a problem. Something bothered you or someone you cared about. You saw a gap, a frustration, a need.

You cared enough to act. Most people notice problems and do nothing. You decided to do something. Why?

You figured something out. Through experience, trial, or study, you learned how to solve it or make progress on it.

Now you are sharing that solution. You are offering your knowledge, skill, or service to others who face the same problem.

That is the arc. Keep it simple and true.

Your credibility does not need to be a degree or a decade of experience. It can be lived experience. It can be intensive research. It can be relatability. I struggled with this too is powerful. I spent 200 hours learning this so you do not have to is powerful.

Do not fake drama. Do not exaggerate. Authenticity beats polish. If your story is simple, keep it simple. Real resonates.

Today you will write three versions of your story: short (50 words), medium (150 words), and full (300 words). Each has its use. The short version is for introductions and bios. The medium is for about pages. The full is for landing pages and sales conversations.

practice.title: The Turning Point Reflection (4-6 minutes)
practice.content:
Set a timer for 5 minutes.

Close your eyes briefly. Think back to the moment when you first noticed the problem your offer solves. Where were you? What triggered it? Who was involved?

Now think about the moment you decided to act. What shifted? Was it frustration reaching a peak? Was it seeing someone else succeed? Was it a specific insight?

Open your eyes and write:

1. The moment I noticed the problem was when _____.
2. What pushed me to act was _____.
3. What I figured out was _____.

These three answers form the skeleton of your story.

mission.task: Complete the Turning Point Reflection practice
Write: when you first noticed the problem
Write: why you cared enough to act
Write: what experience or proof makes you credible
Write: who you want to help
Write: your mission in one sentence
Write: the turning point that made you act
Write your 50-word story
Write your 150-word story
Write your 300-word story
Choose where you will place this story

commonMistakes:
Inventing credentials you do not have. Fake stories backfire. Authenticity matters.

Making it all about you. The story should explain why you can help them, not just why you are great.

Being too vague. I always loved helping people is weak. Be specific about what, when, and how.

Adding unnecessary drama. If your story is simple, keep it simple. Forced drama feels fake.

Using marketing language. Write like a human talking to another human.

Forgetting the mission. Your story should end with what you are offering and why it matters.

Not tying the story to the offer. The story should naturally lead to why your offer exists.

Writing only one version. Different contexts need different lengths. Write all three.
doneMeans: You have a true origin story in three lengths (50, 150, 300 words) and know where you will use it.
reviewCTA: Want feedback on your story? Submit your Day 10 workbook for review and get suggestions on clarity and connection.

title: Assemble the Nuts and Bolts
goal: Create the minimum setup spine so your hustle can launch without chaos
hook: Resourcefulness beats perfection. Today you clear the logistics so you can focus on value and selling.

lesson.title: Why Today Matters
lesson.content:
You have an idea, an avatar, an offer, and a story. Now you need a place to put it all. Today is about logistics, not creativity.

The goal is a setup spine: the minimum operational pieces required to launch. Nothing fancy. Nothing polished. Just the essentials that let you accept money and deliver value.

Here is what a basic spine looks like:

1. A place to explain the offer. This could be a simple landing page, a Google Doc, or even a well-written email. The format matters less than clarity. Can someone read it and understand what they get?

2. A way to capture interest. An email address to contact you, a form to fill out, or a DM button. Make it easy for interested people to raise their hand.

3. A delivery method. How does the customer receive what they paid for? A file sent by email? A scheduling link for a call? A shipped package? Know the mechanism.

4. A basic agreement. What you will do, how much it costs, and when they pay. This does not need to be a legal contract. It can be three lines in an email. Clarity protects both parties.

5. A support channel. An email address where customers can reach you if something goes wrong.

That is the spine. Everything else is optional for now.

Consider Sarah, who wanted to launch a meal planning service. She spent three weeks designing a logo and perfecting her Instagram grid. Meanwhile, her friend Jake wrote a one-page Google Doc explaining his offer, added a PayPal link, and got two paying customers in a week. Jake had a spine. Sarah had decoration.

Make it easier: Start with what you already have. A free Carrd page. A simple Notion doc. Your existing email address. You can upgrade later when you have revenue.

Common mistake: Overbuilding before validation. You do not need a custom website, a full brand package, or automated workflows to make your first sale. You need clarity and a way to get paid.

practice.title: The Launch Spine Audit (5-7 minutes)
practice.content:
Set a timer for 6 minutes.

On paper or in a notes app, draw a simple checklist with these 5 items:

1. Place to explain the offer
2. Way to capture interest
3. Delivery method
4. Basic agreement
5. Support channel

For each item, write what you already have or what you need to create. Be honest. If you have nothing for an item, write nothing.

Now circle the one item that is most urgent. This is the blocker. If you do not solve it, you cannot launch.

Finally, write one resourceful shortcut to get that item done today. Borrow a template. Use a free tool. Ask someone for help. Perfection is not the goal. Done is.

mission.task: Complete the Launch Spine Audit practice
Check off which spine pieces you already have
Identify the biggest missing piece
Find a resourceful shortcut to get it done fast
Identify who or what you can ask for help today
Draft a basic agreement in 3 lines (what, how much, when)
Set up your support email if not already done
Write your next action for the next 24 hours

commonMistakes:
Overbuilding before anyone has paid. You do not need a custom logo, branded templates, or a full website. You need clarity and a payment method.

Waiting for everything to be ready. Launch with 80 percent and fix the rest after you have a customer.

Ignoring the basic agreement. Misunderstandings about scope, price, and timing kill relationships. Write it down, even informally.

Using complexity as an excuse. If your setup feels complicated, simplify it. The best first hustles have three moving parts, not thirty.

Not asking for help. Someone has the template, tool, or knowledge you need. Ask.
doneMeans: You have a documented spine with all 5 pieces either done or scheduled, a basic agreement drafted, and a next action for the next 24 hours.
reviewCTA: Want feedback on your launch spine? Submit your Day 11 workbook for review and get suggestions on simplifying your setup.

title: Decide How to Price Your Offer
goal: Pick a starting price that is not random, not fear-based, and sustainable
hook: No price means hobby. Today you set a number that respects your work and makes sense for your customer.

lesson.title: Why Today Matters
lesson.content:
Many people skip this step or guess at random. They pick a number that sounds nice or copy a competitor without thinking. That is how you end up resenting your own hustle.

Today you will use a simple cost-plus approach to find your minimum workable price. Then you will choose a starting price within a realistic range.

For services:

Start by estimating how many hours it takes to deliver. Be realistic. Include prep time, communication, and follow-up. Multiply by the minimum hourly value you are willing to accept. Then add any direct costs like software or materials. That is your floor.

For products:

Start with your unit cost: materials, production, packaging. Add shipping and platform fees. Then add the minimum profit you need per sale. That is your floor.

Now look at the range. Your floor is the bottom. Your ceiling is what the market will bear. Somewhere in between is your starting price.

Three common pricing models:

Flat package: One price for a defined scope. Works well when you can predict effort.

Hourly: Charge for time. Works when scope varies or customers want flexibility.

Tiered options: Good, better, best. Gives customers choice and anchors them to the middle.

Consider Marcus, who offered resume writing. He charged 25 dollars because he felt nervous. Each resume took him 3 hours. He was earning less than minimum wage and started dreading the work. When he raised his price to 75 dollars, he attracted better clients and enjoyed the process. Underpricing creates hidden damage.

Price sanity check: If you sell 5 units this month, are you happy? If you sell 50, can you deliver? If either answer is no, adjust.

Common mistake: Pricing based on fear instead of value. Your price should cover your costs, respect your time, and leave room to improve the offer.

practice.title: The Cost-Plus Calculation (4-6 minutes)
practice.content:
Set a timer for 5 minutes.

On paper, answer these questions:

1. What is the direct cash cost per sale? (fees, materials, tools)
2. How many hours does it take to deliver one sale?
3. What is the minimum hourly value I want?
4. Minimum price = (hours x hourly value) + cash costs

Now write:

5. My starting price will be _____ because _____.

Finally, consider one higher tier. What could you add to justify a price 50 percent higher? Write it down.

mission.task: Complete the Cost-Plus Calculation practice
Write what you are selling in one sentence
Calculate direct cash cost per sale
Estimate time cost per sale in hours
Decide on your minimum hourly value
Calculate your minimum workable price
Set your starting launch price
Choose a pricing model (flat, hourly, tiered)
Write why this price makes sense and how it feels to publish it

commonMistakes:
Underpricing because of fear. New sellers want to be safe. But too low signals low value and creates resentment.

Pricing without understanding costs. If you do not know your floor, you cannot price sustainably.

Copying competitors without context. Their costs and goals are different. Use their prices as reference, not gospel.

Ignoring time cost. Your hours have value. If you forget to include them, you are subsidizing your customers.

Not doing a sanity check. If 5 sales makes you miserable or 50 sales breaks you, adjust before you launch.
doneMeans: You have a calculated minimum price, a starting launch price, a pricing model chosen, and written reasoning for why it makes sense.
reviewCTA: Want feedback on your pricing logic? Submit your Day 12 workbook for review and get suggestions on positioning.

title: Create a Side Hustle Shopping List
goal: Turn your hustle into a recipe with steps and ingredients so you know what to source
hook: A hustle launches faster when you break it into steps and gather ingredients per step.

lesson.title: Why Today Matters
lesson.content:
Right now your hustle might feel like a cloud of tasks. Today you turn it into a recipe: clear steps with specific ingredients.

Think of it as cooking. You cannot make a cake without knowing the steps and the ingredients. Your hustle is the same.

The 3-step recipe:

Step 1: Create the thing. This is the core value. A draft, a prototype, a lesson, a template, a product. Whatever the customer receives.

Step 2: Put it somewhere. This is where people find it. A page, a listing, a checkout, an email capture. The container.

Step 3: Revenue mechanism. This is how money happens. A payment link, an invoice, a checkout flow, a booking with deposit.

For each step, list the ingredients: tools, resources, deliverables, and skills you need.

Example recipe for a freelance writing service:

Step 1: Create the thing. Ingredients: writing samples, service description, scope template.

Step 2: Put it somewhere. Ingredients: simple website or Notion page, contact form, LinkedIn profile.

Step 3: Revenue mechanism. Ingredients: PayPal account, invoice template, basic contract.

Now you know what to source.

Resourceful sourcing: Borrow before you buy. Use free trials. Buy used. Rent. Trade skills. The goal is to get the ingredient, not to own the fanciest version.

Do not overbuy: Ask yourself, can I launch without this? If yes, defer it. Premature spending kills cash flow and creates pressure.

Common mistake: Buying premium tools before validation. Start with free or cheap. Upgrade when you have revenue.

practice.title: The Recipe Builder (5-7 minutes)
practice.content:
Set a timer for 6 minutes.

Write the 3-step recipe for your hustle:

Step 1: Create the thing. What do I need to make?
Step 2: Put it somewhere. Where will people find it?
Step 3: Revenue mechanism. How does money happen?

For each step, list 2 to 4 ingredients you need.

Circle the one most urgent missing ingredient. This is your blocker.

Write where you will get it within 48 hours. Be specific: a link, a shop, a person, a platform.

mission.task: Complete the Recipe Builder practice
Write your 3-step recipe
List all ingredients you must source or create
List the exact deliverables the customer receives
Identify the single most urgent missing ingredient
Find where you will get it within 48 hours
Choose how you will source it (borrow, free trial, buy used, etc.)
Estimate the cost to acquire the urgent ingredient

commonMistakes:
Not breaking down the hustle into steps. Vague plans create paralysis. Specific recipes create momentum.

Buying premium tools before you have revenue. Start cheap or free. Upgrade later.

Overbuying ingredients. More tools do not equal better results. Minimal is often better.

Forgetting to list deliverables. Know exactly what the customer receives so you can create it.

Not setting a deadline to source the missing ingredient. 48 hours is enough. Longer and you lose momentum.
doneMeans: You have a 3-step recipe, a shopping list grouped by step, the most urgent missing ingredient identified, and a plan to get it within 48 hours.
reviewCTA: Want feedback on your recipe and shopping list? Submit your Day 13 workbook for review.

title: Set Up a Way to Get Paid
goal: Make payment boring, simple, and reliable so you can send a link and get paid today
hook: Money must reach your bank account. Start with simple tech and upgrade later.

lesson.title: Why Today Matters
lesson.content:
You can have the best offer in the world, but if people cannot pay you easily, you will not make money. Today you fix that.

Easy to pay beats fancy payment stack. Your customer should be able to pay in under 2 minutes. Fewer steps, fewer fields, fewer clicks.

Simple options that work:

Stripe: Create a payment link in 5 minutes. Low fees. Works globally.

PayPal: Ubiquitous. Many people already have accounts. Easy invoicing.

Gumroad: Good for digital products. Handles checkout and delivery.

Bank transfer: Works for higher-ticket services where trust already exists.

Invoice tools: Wave, Invoice Ninja, or even a PDF invoice for simple cases.

Understand fees: Most platforms charge 2.9 percent plus a small fixed fee. This affects your real profit. Factor it into your pricing.

Reduce payment friction:

1. Fewer form fields. Name, email, card. That is often enough.
2. Clear refund sentence. People fear commitment. A simple refund policy reduces hesitation.
3. Clear delivery expectations. What happens after they pay? Tell them.

The basic agreement reminder: What you will do, how much, when paid. If you have not written this, do it now. It protects both parties.

Consider this story: Mia set up a payment link but never tested it. Her first customer tried to pay, got an error, and gave up. Mia lost the sale because she skipped the test run. Always test your payment flow end to end before you launch.

Common mistake: Using complicated checkout for a simple offer. If you are selling one thing at one price, a single payment link is enough.

practice.title: The Payment Test Run (5-7 minutes)
practice.content:
Set a timer for 6 minutes.

Open your payment platform of choice. Create a test product or payment link.

Run through the entire flow as if you were the customer:

1. See the offer
2. Click pay
3. Enter details
4. Complete payment
5. Receive confirmation

Note any friction. Too many steps? Confusing fields? Slow loading?

Now write:

1. One-sentence refund policy: Example: Full refund if you are not satisfied within 7 days.
2. One-sentence delivery promise: Example: You will receive the PDF within 24 hours.
3. One-sentence support instruction: Example: Email help@example.com if anything goes wrong.

mission.task: Complete the Payment Test Run practice
Choose your payment method(s) for launch
Set up your payment link or checkout URL
Test the payment flow end to end
Write your one-sentence refund policy
Write your one-sentence delivery promise
Update your basic agreement with payment terms
Confirm your support email is ready

commonMistakes:
Not testing the payment flow. Problems with payment kill sales. Always test before you launch.

Ignoring fees. If you forget to factor in 3 percent fees, you are giving away profit.

Making checkout too complicated. One product, one price, one button. Simple wins.

No refund policy. Silence creates anxiety. Even a clear no-refund policy is better than confusion.

No delivery clarity. Customers want to know what happens after they pay. Tell them.
doneMeans: You have a working payment link, tested the flow end to end, and written your refund policy, delivery promise, and support instruction.
reviewCTA: Want feedback on your payment setup? Submit your Day 14 workbook for review.

title: Design Your First Workflow
goal: Map every step from discovery to payment to delivery so nothing breaks during launch week
hook: A workflow is the sequence that prevents mishaps. Design it from the customer's point of view.

lesson.title: Why Today Matters
lesson.content:
What happens after someone clicks buy? If you do not know, you are not ready to sell. Today you map the complete journey.

A workflow is simply: what happens next. It is a numbered list of steps from the moment someone discovers your offer to the moment they have received value and you have been paid.

The core path:

Discovery: They find your offer. (Social post, search, referral)
Decision: They read and decide to buy.
Payment: They complete checkout.
Confirmation: They get immediate acknowledgment.
Delivery: They receive the value.
Support: They have a way to ask questions.
Follow-up: You check in and ask for feedback or referrals.

What could go wrong:

Customer does not get the confirmation email. Solution: check spam, have a backup message.

Wrong details submitted. Solution: confirmation step that asks them to verify.

Scheduling conflicts with time zones. Solution: use a tool that shows your availability in their timezone.

Refund request. Solution: have a clear policy and a response template ready.

Onboarding messages:

1. Confirmation message: Thank you, here is what happens next.
2. How to start: Brief instructions or login details.
3. Tips: One helpful tip to get value faster.
4. Check-in: A few days later, ask if they need help.

Example workflow for a digital product:

1. Customer finds landing page.
2. Reads offer and clicks buy.
3. Completes Gumroad checkout.
4. Receives confirmation email with download link.
5. Downloads product.
6. Receives follow-up email 3 days later asking for feedback.

Example workflow for a service call:

1. Customer finds landing page.
2. Reads offer and clicks book.
3. Selects time slot via Calendly.
4. Pays via Stripe link.
5. Receives confirmation with call details.
6. Reminder email 24 hours before.
7. Call happens.
8. Follow-up email with summary and next steps.
9. Check-in 1 week later.

Common mistake: Assuming you will figure it out later. The first customer experience shapes whether they recommend you or complain about you.

practice.title: The Workflow Walkthrough (6-8 minutes)
practice.content:
Set a timer for 7 minutes.

Imagine you are the customer. You just found the offer. Walk through every step until you have received the value and the transaction is complete.

Write each step as a numbered list. Include:

1. What the customer does
2. What they see or receive
3. What you do (if anything)

Aim for 10 to 15 steps.

Now pick 2 things that could go wrong. For each, write the fix and the exact message you would send.

mission.task: Complete the Workflow Walkthrough practice
Write your workflow from discovery to delivery (numbered steps)
Write 4 onboarding messages (welcome, how to start, tips, check-in)
Identify what could go wrong (select top risks)
For 2 risks, write the fix and the exact message you will send
Identify one automation or template you will build next
Decide where you will store customer info and orders

commonMistakes:
No workflow at all. Winging it creates mistakes and stress.

Too few steps. If your workflow has 5 steps, you probably forgot something. 10 to 15 is normal.

Ignoring failure scenarios. Things will go wrong. Have a plan.

No onboarding messages. Customers appreciate guidance. Silence after payment feels bad.

Not storing customer info. You need to track who paid and what they received. A simple spreadsheet works.
doneMeans: You have a numbered workflow with at least 12 steps, 4 onboarding messages written, 2 failure scenarios with fixes, and a plan for storing customer info.
reviewCTA: Want feedback on your workflow? Submit your Day 15 workbook for review.

title: Spend 10 Percent More Time on the Most Important Tasks
goal: Stop getting busy with low-value tasks and redirect effort toward benefit and income
hook: When you are unsure what to do, spend at least 10 percent more time on customer benefit and income.

lesson.title: Why Today Matters
lesson.content:
You have been building. But not all building is equal. Some tasks move the needle. Most do not.

The trap of the mundane: It is easy to feel productive tweaking a logo, reorganizing files, or researching competitors for the fifth time. These tasks feel safe. They do not require you to put yourself out there. But they do not generate revenue.

Two things matter:

1. Creating real benefit for customers. Improving the deliverable, clarifying the promise, simplifying onboarding. Anything that makes the customer's experience better.

2. Increasing income for you. Sending outreach, publishing the offer, asking for referrals, following up with leads. Anything that directly leads to money in your account.

The 10 percent rule: Find 30 minutes in your day. Add 3 extra minutes to benefit tasks and 3 extra minutes to income tasks. That is 10 percent more on the work that matters.

The morning 25-minute block: Before distractions hit, spend 25 minutes on one focused build session. Do not check email. Do not browse. Just build or sell.

Decision rule: If the task does not improve benefit or income, pause it. You can return to it after launch. Right now, focus.

Examples of high-impact actions:

Benefit: Record a quick tutorial video, write clearer instructions, add a checklist for customers.

Income: Send 3 outreach messages, post your offer publicly, email past contacts, ask a happy customer for a referral.

Examples of low-value tasks to stop:

Perfecting your logo. Reorganizing your folder structure. Reading one more book about business. Waiting for the perfect moment.

Common mistake: Confusing busy with productive. If you spent 2 hours and did not improve benefit or income, you were not working on the hustle. You were hiding from it.

practice.title: The Priority Audit (4-6 minutes)
practice.content:
Set a timer for 5 minutes.

List everything you have been working on in the past 3 days.

For each item, ask: Did this improve customer benefit? Did this increase income?

Mark each item: B for benefit, I for income, or X for neither.

Count your Xs. These are the tasks to pause.

Now write:

1. Three actions that improve customer benefit (specific)
2. Three actions that increase income (specific)
3. Three tasks to stop doing this week

Finally, schedule a 25-minute morning block for tomorrow and write the exact task you will do.

mission.task: Complete the Priority Audit practice
Rate how clear the customer benefit is today (1-5)
Rate how clear your income plan is today (1-5)
List 3 actions that improve customer benefit
List 3 actions that increase income
List 3 low-value tasks you will stop or postpone
Schedule your 25-minute morning block for tomorrow
Write the exact task you will do in that block

commonMistakes:
Spending time on tasks that feel productive but do not move the needle. Logo design, website polish, and social media setup are rarely essential for the first sale.

Not scheduling focused time. If it is not on the calendar, it will not happen.

Waiting for motivation. Do the 25 minutes even when you do not feel like it.

Not asking for the sale. Outreach feels uncomfortable, but it is the fastest path to income.

Overcomplicating benefit. Sometimes the simplest improvement, like clearer instructions, has the biggest impact.
doneMeans: You have listed 3 benefit actions, 3 income actions, 3 tasks to stop, and scheduled a 25-minute morning block for tomorrow with a specific task.
reviewCTA: Want feedback on your priorities? Submit your Day 16 workbook for review.

title: Publish Your Offer!
goal: Make your offer available for purchase somewhere public

lesson.title: Why Today Matters
lesson.content:
This is the day. Whatever you've built—simple or complex—it's time to make it available to the world. The gap between 'working on it' and 'it's live' is one click.

Publishing doesn't mean perfect. It means available. Someone, somewhere, can now see your offer and decide whether to buy.

This might be a simple landing page, a product listing on a marketplace, or even a direct message to your first prospect. The format matters less than the action.

Hit publish. You can improve it later.

mission.task: Finalize your sales page/listing with offer details and price
Test the complete flow: view offer, click buy, complete payment
Publish it—make it accessible via a live URL or marketplace
Share the link somewhere (one post, one message, one email)

commonMistakes: Don't delay for perfection. A live imperfect offer beats a perfect offer that no one can see. You can iterate after you publish.
doneMeans: Your offer has a live, public URL and you've shared it with at least one person or channel.

title: Sell Like a Girl Scout
goal: Directly ask potential customers to buy

lesson.title: Why Today Matters
lesson.content:
Girl Scouts don't wait for customers to find their cookie table. They knock on doors, set up in high-traffic areas, and ask directly. Today, you do the same.

Direct outreach isn't spam—it's service. If your offer genuinely helps people, telling them about it is a favor, not an imposition.

The key is targeting. Don't blast everyone; reach out to people who actually fit your ideal customer profile. Personalize. Explain why you thought of them. Make it easy to say yes or no.

mission.task: Identify 10 specific people who match your ideal customer profile
Write a personalized outreach message (not a template)
Send your offer to all 10 people via appropriate channels
Track responses: who replied, what did they say?

commonMistakes: Don't apologize for selling. 'Sorry to bother you' signals that you don't believe in your offer. Be direct and confident.
doneMeans: You've personally reached out to 10 potential customers with your offer.

title: Ask Ten People for Help
goal: Leverage your network for introductions and feedback

lesson.title: Why Today Matters
lesson.content:
Beyond direct sales, your network can amplify your reach. Today you ask for help—not sales, but introductions, shares, and feedback.

People want to help, but they need to be asked specifically. 'Can you share this?' is better than hoping they notice. 'Do you know anyone who…?' is better than waiting for referrals.

The ask should be easy to fulfill. Don't ask people to write a novel—ask them to forward an email, share a link, or make an introduction.

mission.task: Identify 10 people in your network who might help (not buy)
Write a simple ask: share, introduce, or give feedback
Send your ask to all 10 people
Note: who said yes? What did they offer?

commonMistakes: Don't be vague. 'Let me know if you can help' gets ignored. 'Would you share this with your newsletter?' gets action.
doneMeans: You've asked 10 people for specific help and documented their responses.

title: Test, Test, and Test Again
goal: Gather feedback and iterate on your offer

lesson.title: Why Today Matters
lesson.content:
By now you've put your offer in front of people. Some may have bought; many probably haven't. Today is about understanding why.

Feedback is data. Why did people say no? What questions did they ask? What confused them? Each response is a clue for improving your offer.

Don't get defensive about feedback. Your first version was a hypothesis. Real market response tells you whether that hypothesis was right.

mission.task: Review all responses from Days 17-19: what patterns emerge?
Identify the most common objections or questions
Make at least one improvement to your offer or messaging
Follow up with anyone who said 'maybe' or asked questions

commonMistakes: Don't take rejection personally. Every 'no' is information about how to get to 'yes.' Stay curious, not wounded.
doneMeans: You've documented feedback patterns and made at least one concrete improvement.

title: Burn Down the Furniture Store
goal: Create urgency with a legitimate limited-time offer

lesson.title: Why Today Matters
lesson.content:
Sometimes people need a reason to act now instead of 'later' (which usually means 'never'). Today you create legitimate urgency around your offer.

This isn't about fake scarcity or manipulation. It's about giving people a real reason to decide: a limited-time discount, a bonus that expires, a cohort that's filling up.

Urgency works because it forces a decision. Without a deadline, 'maybe' stretches indefinitely. With a deadline, people must choose.

mission.task: Design a time-limited offer (discount, bonus, or limited availability)
Set a specific deadline (real, not fake)
Communicate the offer to your audience (new post, email, update)
Prepare to follow up before the deadline expires

commonMistakes: Don't create fake urgency that you'll extend later. People remember and trust erodes. If the deadline passes, honor it.
doneMeans: You have a published time-limited offer with a real deadline.

title: Frame Your First Dollar
goal: Celebrate and document your first sale

lesson.title: Why Today Matters
lesson.content:
Whether you've made a sale already or you're still working toward it, today is about the milestone of the first dollar.

If you've made a sale: celebrate it. Document exactly what happened—the channel, the person, the moment. This is the proof that your side hustle works.

If you haven't yet: analyze why and plan your next actions. The first sale often takes longer than expected. That's normal. Keep going.

The first dollar matters more than the amount. It's proof of concept.

mission.task: Document any sales so far: amount, channel, customer details
If no sale yet: list the three most likely paths to first sale
Identify what made the sale happen (or what's blocking it)
Write a 'first dollar story' you could share

commonMistakes: Don't discount the first sale because it was 'just a friend' or 'only $20.' Revenue is revenue. Start celebrating small wins.
doneMeans: You've documented your first sale (or a concrete plan to get it) and reflected on what worked.

title: Track Your Progress and Decide on Next Steps
goal: Review your metrics and plan for the coming weeks

lesson.title: Why Today Matters
lesson.content:
Data beats intuition. Today you step back and look at the numbers: views, clicks, responses, sales. What story do they tell?

Without tracking, you're guessing. With tracking, you're learning. Even if the numbers are small, the patterns reveal what's working and what's not.

Based on this data, you'll make informed decisions about where to focus your energy in the coming weeks.

mission.task: Gather all metrics: page views, click rates, responses, sales
Calculate conversion rates at each stage of your funnel
Identify the biggest bottleneck (where are people dropping off?)
List three specific actions to improve the bottleneck

commonMistakes: Don't panic over small sample sizes. A 0% conversion rate from 5 visitors means nothing statistically. Focus on getting more data first.
doneMeans: You have a documented metrics dashboard and a list of specific improvements to make.

title: Grow What Works, Let Go of What Doesn't
goal: Double down on successes and abandon failures

lesson.title: Why Today Matters
lesson.content:
Not everything you tried worked. That's expected. Today you make hard decisions about what to continue, what to amplify, and what to kill.

Effective strategy is as much about stopping as starting. Every minute spent on something that isn't working is a minute not spent on something that could.

Look at your data from Day 23. What channel brought the most interest? What message resonated? What fell flat? Invest more in winners, cut the losers.

mission.task: Identify your top-performing channel, message, and tactic
Identify what clearly isn't working (cut it)
Plan how to 2x your effort on what's working
Update your strategy document with these decisions

commonMistakes: Don't keep investing in tactics just because you spent time on them. Sunk cost is irrelevant. Only future potential matters.
doneMeans: You've made concrete decisions about what to invest in and what to stop.

title: Look for Money Lying Under a Rock
goal: Find overlooked revenue opportunities in your existing setup

lesson.title: Why Today Matters
lesson.content:
Sometimes the best opportunities are hiding in plain sight. Today you look for money you're leaving on the table—upsells, add-ons, referral opportunities, or underpriced services.

Ask: who's already interested but hasn't bought? What else could current customers need? Where is demand showing up that you haven't addressed?

These 'rocks' often represent easier revenue than acquiring entirely new customers. The hardest sale is the first one; subsequent sales to satisfied customers are much easier.

mission.task: List everyone who showed interest but didn't buy
Identify potential upsells or add-ons for current customers
Look for referral opportunities from happy customers
Choose one 'rock' to pursue this week

commonMistakes: Don't only chase new customers while ignoring warm leads. The people who already said 'maybe' are often closest to saying 'yes.'
doneMeans: You've identified hidden revenue opportunities and picked one to pursue.

title: Get It Out of Your Head
goal: Document your systems so the side hustle can run without you

lesson.title: Why Today Matters
lesson.content:
Right now, your side hustle lives in your head. That's a risk. If you get busy with life, sick, or just need a break, everything stops.

Today you document. Write down your workflows, your systems, your checklists. Create simple documentation that your future self (or someone else) could follow.

This isn't about building a corporation. It's about creating clarity and resilience. A documented system is easier to improve, easier to delegate, and easier to resume after a break.

mission.task: Document your customer acquisition workflow (how do people find you?)
Document your sales process (how do people buy?)
Document your delivery process (how do you fulfill?)
Create a one-page 'operations summary'

commonMistakes: Don't over-document. You're not writing a corporate manual. Simple bullet points are fine. Clarity beats comprehensiveness.
doneMeans: Your core processes are documented and you could hand them to someone else.

title: Back to the Future
goal: Set your vision and plan for the next 90 days

lesson.title: Why Today Matters
lesson.content:
Congratulations—you've completed the 27-day program. You've moved from idea to offer to (hopefully) first sales. That's not nothing. That's real progress.

But a side hustle isn't a project; it's an ongoing practice. Today you zoom out and plan what happens next.

What did you learn? What would you do differently? What are your goals for the next 90 days? The work continues, but now you have momentum, experience, and data to guide you.

mission.task: Write a 'retrospective': what worked, what didn't, what surprised you
Set specific goals for the next 90 days (revenue, customers, product)
Identify the single biggest lever to pull in the next month
Schedule recurring time for your side hustle going forward

commonMistakes: Don't stop now because 'the program is over.' The program was the beginning. The side hustle continues.
doneMeans: You've completed a retrospective, set 90-day goals, and scheduled ongoing time for your side hustle.
